text: JAKE, a four year old boy, sits in a bathtub. The door to bathroom is open and his mother is visible in the backgro walking back and forth in the bedroom, getting dressed to out. The STEREO is blaring in the bedroom, the music echo off the tile in the tiny bathroom. Jake is playing with a plastic airplane. He answers a question.
(PAUSE)
Sometimes. (PAUSE)

With my toys. He looks up, but we're close in on him and can't see who looking at. JAKE (cont'd) My... blue sword. No! The one with the gray tape around the middle. That one. He lands the airplane on the water. He giggles. JAKE (coast' d) That's silly. MAGGIE (o.s.) (from the bedroom) Jake? You all right in there?
(calling out to the door)
The airplane takes off again. Jake lowers his voice to a whisper. JAKE (cont'd) What? (PAUSE)
My daddy, but he doesn't know about it yet. He brings the airplane in for a careful water landing and go of it. He looks up. (CONTINUED)

JAKE (cont' d) Can I ask you a question? He pauses, looks to the door to make sure his mother isn' close. Moving back now, we see that Jake is all alone in bathroom, staring at the empty bathtub across from him. JAKE (cont'd) Does it hurt to be dead?
the toy airplane sinks and crash lands on the bottom of t tub.
MAGGIE WITZKY, twenty-six or seven, Jake's mom, city girl knows how to take care of herself, pokes her head in the doorway, buttoning up her blouse.
Who you talkin' to, Jake? He turns to her and whispers.
It's a secret.
TOM WITZKY, Maggie's age, lean and muscled like somebody works for a living, lies on Jake's bed next to his son, reading him a story. Jake is nearly asleep.

Well, I was walking in the night, and I saw nothing scary. For I have never been afraid of anything. Not very. I was deep within the woods when, suddenly, I spied them. I saw a pair of pale green pants with nobody inside them! I wasn't scared. But, yet, I stopped. What could those pants be there for? What could a pair of pants at night be standing in the air for? Maggie leans in the doorway and whispers.
Is he asleep? My brother's here. (CONTINUED)

Tom looks at Jake, who is asleep. Tom closes the book, tu off the light, and covers his son. He kisses him on the forehead. Tom goes to a dresser and turns on the baby mon (the transmitter). Its red light glows. After Tom leaves, Jake opens his eyes and stares.

The Chicago skyline looms over the street they live on. N the suburbs, but not quite downtown either. Racially mixe Two story brick houses jammed side by side, barely room f raised voice across the narrow driveways. Bar on the corn neon sign -- "BERNIE'S TAP." A HOMELESS GUY rants his way down the opposite sidewalk. Tom, Maggie, and PHILIP, early twenties, come out of the and head down the steps. Tom carries the baby monitor (th receiver) in one hand. Jake's breathing is clearly audibl the speaker. Tom's on the sidewalk. Maggie, still three steps up, stop and puts her arms wide. Tom turns around and Maggie lets herself go, falling straight forward. Tom catches her on back and carries her piggy-back. She leans around and bit his ear.
What are the odds of a single woman being at this thing?
`Bout a million to one.
Any hot mommies?

Depends. How big you like `em? The hot engine of a Yellow Trans-Am fires up in the drive of the house across the street. It backs into the street, passenger door hanging open. The DRIVER honks the horn an SEVENTEEN YEAR OLD KID runs out of another house and jump into the moving vehicle. They take off. The Homeless Guy berates them, shaking his fist. They reach the steps of the house next door. PARTY NOISE comes from within, shadows move in the windows. Tom swing Maggie around, puts her on the step, wraps his arms aroun her, and kisses her. Great kiss. It goes on. (CONTINUED)
Excuse me, hello, I enjoy soft-core as much as the next guy, but this is almost like incest for me.
(still kissing Tom) Should we tell him?
Sure.
I'm pregnant.

Get the fuck outta here! He grabs Maggie and hugs her. Tom starts up the steps. PHILIP (cont' d) Look at this, I haven't even had a second date in a year and a half, you guys are on your second kid! Philip catches up to Tom and throws his arms around him. PHILIP (cont' d) You big huggable bear. You're still goin' back to school, though, right? You promised me.
I don't know, I just found out about this.
I'm telling you, if you never go back to college you'll regret it for the rest of your life. The memories I have of being a freshman -- those were three of the happiest years of my life.
TWENTY OR THIRTY PEOPLE are crowded into a living room. I loud, smoky, there's music and a ton of booze -- empty be bottles, five gallon jugs of wine, big liter bottles of v and gin. (CONTINUED)
The men are mostly on one side, women on the other. As Ma heads toward the women, Tom grabs her arm and pulls her b close.

Seven years, and I've still never been to a party where you weren't the one I wanted to hang with. She smiles, melted, and they part. Tom joins the men. BOB Vanessa's husband, an athletic-looking guy holding a slee three-year-old on his shoulder, talks with FRANK McCARTHY fortyish, big Irish drinker, and HARRY DAMON, who is also older than the rest.
Tom-Tom-Tommy, how are ya? He shoves a beer into Tom's hand.
Alive on the planet. (nods to Harry) Harry.
Hello, Tom. Takin' care of the place?
Actually, I'm drillin' holes in all the floors, Harry.
(as Tom drinks) That's it, take the medicine deep into your body. Good, good.
So how you likin' the neighborhood?
Well, I grew up about a mile from here, it ain't like a foreign country.
The hell it isn't! This is the best God damn neighborhood in Chicago, `cause we look out for each other, and that's sayin' a lot as we approach the Year of our Lord two thousand.
What are you, runnin' for Mayor? (CONTINUED)
LENNY, the local crank, pipes up.
Hey, did any of you guys see those Dominican crack dealers hangin' around the park again? Everybody GROANS.
(to Bobby) What is Lenny doing here? Did you tell him you were having a party?!
Vanessa made me.
Yeah, laugh it up, laugh it up, and when you all wake up dead with your throats cut some night --
I mean, I could see if he just heard the noise and wandered in, but to actually invite him into your home.. .
-- don't come cryin' to me!
Philip surveys the selection of females. He sees VANESSA, late twenties, hasn't lost the weight from the last baby
Not attracted to... -- SHEILA, a thin, nervous woman around Frank's age -- PHILIP (cont' d) Not drunk enough for... -- and a LOUD WOMAN with enormous hair. PHILIP (cont' d) Frightened by...
everyone has eaten, some have left, the ones that remain bombed. A DRUNK COUPLE dances dirty. Frank stares long an hard at someone's cleavage. (CONTINUED)

Sheila, the nervous woman, stares at Frank, pissed off. H looks at her, gives her a "What?" gesture. Must be marrie each other. Tom, on the other side of the room, hears a SHRIEK of wom voice: and turns. He sees Maggie blushing, receiving hugs congrLtulations from the two or three women around her.
Vanessa talks to Maggie while she mixes up a blender of Margaritas. The room is jammed with people.
How did you and Tom meet?
He saved my life.
No, really.

I'm serious. The summer I was nineteen, I was at Jones Beach, I swam out too far and got a cramp in my leg. There was no way I was gonna make it back. I was goin' down, I was swallowing water and everything. Tom was a lifeguard. I don't know what he was doing out that far, he said he just had a feeling.
Oh my God, did you have sex with him like, that night?
Had to. He said I'm his slave until I saved him back.
That's so romantic. Bobby and I met when I peed in the guys' john at a Bon Jovi concert. She hits "puree" on the blender.

the party's down to the hard-core half dozen, who are pas a joint. Tom sits on the couch, feet on the coffee table to their baby monitor. Maggie is next to him, Frank and Sheila are jammed in there too. (CONTINUED)
Bobby and Vanessa sit on the floor opposite. Philip is in chair at the end.
P(ople who say they were hypnotized weren't really, they were just, you kn)w, playing along.
Then how could they have needles stuck into their throats without bleeding? Without even making a sound?
Bullshit.
You never saw that happen.
Uh, hello, I had a two inch needle stuck right into the thick of my arm, by my professor, while I was under hypnosis.
Bullshit!
You're making it up!
That's disgusting!
I saw his arm the next day. It left a mark.
Bullshit!
Can you learn another word?
Prove it.
Yeah, let's see.
Hypnotize somebody. Hypnotize Vanessa. (CONTINUED)
Oh, no. Uh uh.
Why not?

Because, I .night make a fool out of myself! I n. ;.ght, I don't know, expose myself or sowething. She clutches her arms around her breasts as she says that You get the feeling she'd like to expose herself.
I thought you didn't believe in it.
I don't, but -- do Maggie.
Yeah, right.
You do it, Sheila. We promise not to make you do a strip tease on the kitchen table. Sheila glares at him. They must be fun to hang out with.
That's what I'd do! That's exactly the kind of thing I'm afraid I'd do!
Hey Frank, you're the one who's so curious, why don't you-
No.
Ah, that's different. Whaddya got to hide?
No fuckin' way, I ain't gonna do it. Tom sits forward.
What the hell? I'll try anything once.

a hand switches off the lamp on the table. Another hand turns off the lamp in the corner. The music is turned off. Tom sits in the armchair in the n3arly-darkened room. Phi shoves the coffee table back and sits on it, directly in of him. The others crowd around expectantly, silent.
No sound.from anyone, please. Any distraction can break it up. He raises his index finger and holds it about a foot in f of Tom's face. PHILIP (cont' d) Okay. Look at it.
Damn fine lookin' finger. Laughter.
(AUTHORITATIVE)
Be quiet. (they do) Look at it. Keep looking at it. Don't look at anything else, just my finger.
Can you clean out the nail, it's kinda makin' me sick here. Philip raises two fingers and jabs Tom in the eyes. TOM (cont' d) Hey, what the fuck?
Shall we try this again?
(rubbing his eyes) Asshole. (CONTINUED)
Look at me, Tom. You're not afraid of this. You want this to happen. Don't you?
Poke me again you son of a batch and I'll clock you, I swear to Go'..
Philip, have you ever done this before?
Maggie, please, I nearly have a master's degree in cognitive psy-
Have you ever done it before?
Well, I've seen it done a dozen times.
Try not to screw him up permanently.
(to Tom) You want to be hypnotized. Say yes.
Yeah.
"I want to be hypnotized."
I want to be fuckin' hypnotized, already.
Okay. Close your eyes. As Tom does, our eyes close too, big heavy lashes droppin over everything and plunging us into blackness. PHILIP (o.s.) Just listen for a moment.

we can still hear the sounds of the living room. Tom breathes. Ice CLINKS in a glass as someone drinks. A car HUMS by outside. PHILIP (o.s.) Now look at the backs of your eyelids. Do you see anything there? TOM (o.s.) Uh... Out of the pitch black, we can detect tiny images. TOM (o.s.) Some colors... something floating... up. PHILIP (o . s . ) Focus on it. A small squiggly line comes into focus, drifting up throu the black, then bouncing suddenly downward. PHILIP (o.s.) Now... I want you to pretend you're in a theatre.
We're sitting in a theatre, a bare stage at the front. PHILIP (o . s . ) A movie theatre.

Okay, we're sitting in a movie theatre. It's crowded with people, waiting for the movie to start. PHILIP (o.s.) You're the only one there. The people disappear. The theatre is empty. PHILIP (o . s . ) You're sitting near the front. We pop up ten rows closer to the screen. (CONTINUED)

PHILIP (o . s . ) The walls of the theatre are black, covered with black velvet. SHOOOP! Black velvet descends over the walls. PHILIP (o . s . ) The seats are covered with black velvet. Black velvet crawls over the seats. PHILIP (o . s . ) There is no light in the theatre. The lights click off. PHILIP (o . s . ) In the whole pitch-black theatre, there's only one thing you can see. The white screen. You drift toward it, in your chair. Up ahead of us, the screen is a dazzling white. We move slowly toward it, floating over the seats. PHILIP (o . s . ) There are letters up on the screen. Tall, thick, black letters, but they're out of focus. You drift closer to them, trying to read them. Blurry black letters appear on the screen. We drift close PHILIP (o. s . ) You're comfortable in your black velvet seat, very comfortable. You just sit there, looking at the screen, drifting closer in your chair, staring at those letters on the screen. You're relaxing. Your feet and ankles are relaxed. Your legs are relaxed. Your hands are limp and heavy. Your arms are relaxed. Your face. The letters come into focus, you're close enough now, you can read them. The letters are right in front of us now, but still blurr PHILIP (o . s . ) The letters spell -- (CONTINUED)

The moment he speaks the word, five giant black letters c into focus on the white screen, filling our entire field vision. PHILIP (o . s . ) SLEEP. We stare at that word for a moment -- -- and then everything goes black. No sound, no image, no nothing. And then...
Six faces stare right at us from up close. Tom is in the chair, eyes open, looking disoriented.

Didn't work, huh? All six faces burst out laughing, a great nervous tension released. Somebody turns the lights back on, somebody els hits the music. TOM (cont' d) What? More laughter. Philip seems very pleased with himself. Maggie comes and sits on the arm of the chair next to Tom puts her hand on his face.
Are you okay?
Did somethin' happen? People start talking, all at once.
You were faking it. You had to be faking it.
What are you talking about?
That was the weirdest thing I've ever seen in my whole fuckin' life.
How do you feel? (CONTINUED)
How am I supposed to feel?
A little.., hot, maybe? EveryboJy laughs again. Tom wipes his forehead. He's cove with sweat. He gets up. He doesn't like this at all, bein the only one not in on the joke.
What'd you do to me?

Nothing much. Just had you stretched out as stiff as a board between those two chairs -- He points to two dining room chairs that are sitting back back four or five feet apart. PHILIP (cont' d) (lighting a lighter) -- and ran this back and forth under your legs. Tom feels the backs of his legs. He looks at Maggie.
That happened?
You said it didn't hurt at all. And he kept it moving.
Hey, thanks a lot, it was very nice of you not to burn my flesh.
Joey Ariola woulda burned it. They laugh again. Tom looks at him, stunned.
Who?
The kid who beat you up all the time when you were twelve. You told us all about him. You were cryin' and everything. (CONTINUED)
Tom seethes, humiliated. Vanessa looks at her watch.
(low, to Vanessa) Don't.
Not time yet.
What?
(INNOCENTLY)
Huh?
Not time for what?
Tom, you didn't do anything embarrassing or anything.
Aright, somebody else go. Come on, let's go, somebody else, right now.
Tom, look --
Nobody? Well, then I guess the party's over, ain't it? (to Maggie) Let's go. Come on, let's go home.
You're getting a little too worked up about this.

You know, I don't think so, because I'll tell you something, it's a very nasty feeling to know somebody's been fuckin' around in your head for everybody else's amusement, you know? (lightening up a bit) I mean, Joey Ariola, Christ, I haven't thought about him in maybe ten years, and -- come on, man, somebody else has gotta go. Don't make me be the only- (CONTINUED)

On the mantle over the fireplace, a clock CHIMES. Everyon immediately silent, staring at Tom. He looks at the clock It's eleven. He lifts his foot, pulls off his shoe -- -- and throws it out the window. There is an explosion of laughter.
Why'd you do that, Tom?
I... have no idea. Even more laughter, now everybody's slapping him on the b Tom nods, "yeah, yeah, laugh it up."
I couldn't resist. Tom cranks an arm around Philip's neck and pulls him down choking him. But it's playful, his sense of humor returni
Any other surprises you left in my head, you fuckin' dead man, you?
It's dark. Tom and Maggie lie in bed, awake.

I hope it's a girl, I can't help it. Six brothers, I mean, give me a break. I'm sick of all these balls around the house. He doesn't laugh. She rolls over, strokes his chest with hand. MAGGIE (cont' d) What's the matter?
Two kids. I'm only twenty-six. How did this happen? She slides one hand down, under the covers. (CONTINUED)
(imitating him) "Please, baby, please baby, just this one time, I can't feel anything with one of those on."
No, I now how it happened, I'm just sayin'... You're gonna have to stop work, at least for a while. I'll be workin' Saturdays for at least another year, maybe two.
You don't have to. We'll get by, we always do. Tom stares at a dark brown water stain on the ceiling.
How many times I gotta ask Harry to fix that? He said he fixed this place up, so how come the roof leaks every time it rains?
Relax. Her hand is moving. He twists.
Maggie, you don't think, I mean, ten, twelve years from now... I don't want you to think I'm gonna be a line man forever, you know, like Frank or somethin'.
It's a good job. You know how many guys would kill for your job?
I'm smarter than that, I know I am.
(kisses his ear) Relax. She's making it hard for him to concentrate. (CONTINUED)

I'm smarter than Philip, Christ, six years in college, he's still got his head up his ass. I just want you to know, this ain't where I plan to stop. She licks his ear. He closes his eyes. TOM (cont' d) All my life, I feel like there's something better inside me, it's trying like hell to get out and it's like x won't let it. She rolls on top of him and whispers.
Let me help.
the clock reads 2:31 a.m. Maggie is asleep, Tom is lying his back, still awake. He looks over at the clock, agitated. He stares up at the ceiling. He closes his eyes.

races across the back of his eyelids: -- Philip's face, close to his, a finger held in front of -- A flame, leaping out from a cigarette lighter. Six more faces, pressed in close to his. Himself, floating in an armchair above an empty movie theatre.
Tom snaps his eyes open. He rolls over onto his side, punching his pillow. He closes his eyes again.
faster this time. We share his point of view: -- A twelve year old boy beats us up in an alley near a dumpster. -- A fourteen year old girl kisses us behind a brick buil (CONTINUED)

-- A vicious dog sinks its teeth into our calf. -- Maggie, drowning, reaches out to us. The images Increase in speed, a half a dozen flip by so f they're almcst subliminal -- a car tire, a broken arm, fa into water, breaking window, ham and eggs, a bolt of lightning.
Tom sits up abruptly, shaking his head to clear it.
.the fuck, man? He puts his hands to the side of his head. It hurts. A lo Maggie stirs, but doesn't wake up. Tom gets up and walks As he passes Jake's room, he does a double take.
the four year old is awake. Not just awake, but standing to his bed, perfectly straight, staring at the open doorw Tom steps in. He can see by the light of the nightlight.
(WHISPERS)

Jake? The little boy doesn't answer. Tom walks slowly over to t boy and squats down in front of him, putting his arms on boy's shoulders. TOM (cont' d) Are you okay? Jake just looks at Tom, straight into his father's eyes. boy's face lights up in a wide smile. He reaches out with hand and rests his fingertips on Tom's forehead.
Don't be afraid of it, Daddy. The hell does that mean? But before Tom can respond, Jake turns, climbs back in be rolls over to face the wall, and goes back to sleep.

Tom shakes some Advil into his palm; washes three down wi glass of water. He runs water in the sink, splashes some his face. He straigltens, looks in the mirror as he wipes dripping face. He stares at himself for a moment, then summons his nerve and closes his eyes.

more images come. -- The front of Tom's own house, from a distance. A MAN I OVERCOAT stands on the porch, waving to us to come in. -- Rough hands attack us, covering our eyes and face. -- A face, close to ours but blurry and distorted, as if through dirty, blue-tinted eyeglasses. -- Wooden floorboards as we race down toward them. We hit hard, and our blood sprays out onto the wood.
Tom's eyes pop open. That was disturbing.

Tom strides into the living room. Their house is small, crowded with kids' toys and furniture they got for their wedding. Tom paces back and forth, holding his head in hi hands. He turns and bolts into the kitchen.

Tom rips the refrigerator open and searches the top shelf finds what he's looking for, a large carton of orange jui He opens a cabinet, takes out a glass and fills it. He upends the glass, drains it in one gulp. Still unsatisfied, he picks up the carton. He drinks the rest. Juice runs down his chin.

Tom drops onto the sofa. He sits for a moment, trying to regain himself. His breathing returns to normal. He sits forward, picks up the remote off the coffee table, points at the TV and turns it on. When he sits back -- -- there's a woman sitting next to him. (CONTINUED)

She's eighteen or nineteen years old, so pale her skin's almost luminous. She's attractive but odd, she wears a billowy black dress with a diamond pattern, bangles up an down each wrist. Her lips are light blue, her eyes red- rimmed. Steam rises softly from her hair and skin; when s speaks, her breath comes out of her mouth in clouds of va

You can kiss me if you want to. Tom bolts to his feet and staggers away from the couch. T woman stares intently at him and says something else, but words are lost under the rising sound of static on the television.

What?! She repeats, but he can only see her lips moving, the wor are lost under the static. Realizing, Tom turns hurriedly toward the TV and hits the mute switch. When he turns bac -- the woman is gone. He stands in the middle of the room looking all around him. But he's alone.
Tom crawls back into bed and pulls the blankets up tight around him. He's shivering.
drops over him and he nearly jumps out of his skin. It's Maggie, rolling over to embrace him in her sleep. He take her hand in his and lies still, eyes wide open.

Morning. Tom and Maggie sit at the kitchen table. From th living room, we can hear a-kids' morning show on the television. Tom is wearing jeans and a phone company unif shirt. Maggie is staring at him. They keep their voices l
What do you mean, like... You mean like a hallucination?
Maybe. I was awake, I know that. She nods, thinking, no idea how to deal with this. (CONTINUED)
Did you, uh, get her name?
You know, she didn't menti. -in it.
You sure you weren't dreami.g?
Positive. I had this headache like you wouldn't believe, and I was thirsty as hell.
What should we do? You want to call Philip?
Yeah, I'll call him. But I don't think he's got a fuckin' clue in life. From the living room, Jake laughs uproariously at somethi the TV.
How about my cousin Elizabeth?
I don't need brain surgery, I just had a weird thing happen, that's all. Like a hypnosis hangover. One-time deal, don't worry about it.
Well, if anything like this happens again, we should go talk to Elizabeth.
Maggie...
Promise me.
I promise.

There's a pickup football game in the street, a half a do sixteen and seventeen year olds timing their plays to coi with the red lights. Tom gets into a pickup truck with a phone compaty logo on door, starts it up, and pulls forward to the neat house. hits the horn. While he waits, he turns and loo--s back u the front of his own house.

one of the images that blasted through his mind last nigh It's his own house, on a wintry day. A man in an overcoat standing on the porch, waving an arm in a friendly way -- "C'mon in." But the image is silent, slow and eerie. We m slowly toward the porch, toward the man in the overcoat.
Tom turns slowly away from his house, just as

BANGS off his windshield, nearly breaking it. TWO BODIES hurtle through the air and land on his hood with a loud m CLANG. Tom jumps a foot. He gets out of the car. ADAM McCARTHY, seventeen, climbs off the hood, embarrassed.

Jesus, you guys scared the shit out of me! The kid with Adam doesn't seem embarrassed, he just reach for the football. Tom beats him to it. TOM (cont' d) You gotta play right here in the middle of the street? Frank is out of his house now, approaching the truck. He wears the same uniform shirt as Tom, carries a tool belt his shoulder.
Lighten up, Tommy, you sound like your own grandfather . (CONTINUED)
(looking at his hood) Aw man, it's dented. This ain't even my truck. They're gonna dock me for this.
That'll pop right out. Use one of them plunger things. Adam, say you're sorry.
I'm really sorry, Mr. Witzky.

There you go, he said he's sorry, whaddya want from a kid. Let's go. Frank gets in the truck. The other football players walk toward Tom, calling for the ball. KURT DAMON, a great-loo seventeen year old, stares pointedly at the ball in Tom's hand. Tom looks at him.
Hell of an arm ya got there. Kurt smiles and shrugs. Tom tosses the ball back to him. Kurt turns and catches it behind his back as he walks awa
Tom gets back in and closes the door.
That Damon kid, he's gonna break your old passing records this Friday.
Bound to happen some time.
Comin' to the game?

(starts the car) Yeah, I'm comin', I'm comin' HARRY (o.s.) Hey, Tom! Tom turns. Harry Damon, the guy from across the street, i headed toward him. But Tom notices something behind Harry police car has turned onto the block and is rolling to a (CONTINUED)

The UNIFORMED COP behind the wheel is staring out the win looking right at Tom. Harry comes up to the open window and starts talking, but is looking past him, at the Cop, who has stopped now. HARRY (cont' d) Thought I'd stop by and pick up the rent. Save you the trip across the street.
It's still two days yet, isn't it? Tom looks more closely at the Cop. He realizes the Cop is looking at him, he's looking past him, toward Tom's house
Yeah, just thought you'd want to get it out of your hair.
(DISTRACTED)
Well, my checkbook's inside.
I can wait. Hey, Frank, some game we picked to miss last night, huh? How many yards Adam end up with? Tom turns in his seat, following the Cop's line of vision

Two hundred eleven and two touchdowns. Harry lets out a low whistle. Tom sees what the Cop is looking at so intently -- it's Jake, who's playing on the sidewalk in front of their house while Maggie watches. To turns back, but as he does the police car is just pulling away.
The signal division of the local phone company has a larg main floor. A twenty-foot wall on one side of the room sh a forest of jagged, blinking lines.
Tom is wedged between giant walls of circuit boards. He p a red circuit clip from his belt and picks a line at rand (CONTINUED)

He pulls up the test handset unit that hangs from'his bel listens, hoping from a dial tone. Instead, he cuts in on WOMAN'S VOICE. VOICE (o.s.) (on phone line) -which was okay, I guess, but then he told me he loves me, and it was just like, oh my God, can you please make yourself any less attractive? Tom pulls off the clip and picks another line. Now it's a SNEAKY MAN'S VOICE. VOICE (o.s.) -unless they find out we already locked in with Cooper at eighty, so it's imperative we lead them to believe we're honestly trying to-, Tom clips to another line. It's a SEXY WOMAN'S VOICE. VOICE (o.s.) -start at my lips and lick your way all the way down to my- Tom starts to unclip, then hesitates, only human. The voi abruptly changes. VOICE (coast' d) Hey, did somebody pick up on your end? Is your wife there? Tom unclips and picks another line. He gets a dial tone. enters a number on his headset. A SLEEPY VOICE answers.
Phil, it's Tom. Is there anything else important you said to me last night, while I was under?

Philip (Maggie'a brother) is still in bed in his apartmen It's a smallish place, one wall is all windows with a lov view of a factory, its stacks belching black smoke into t air. Philip's hung over. He holds the phone like he resen it.
What time is it? (CONTINUED)
TOM (o.a.) Quarter after eight. What are you, still in bed?
Quarter after eight? Jesus, Tom, this is barbaric. (INTERCUT)
Other than the shoe thing, what else did you say to me?
Hang on, lemme, I gotta get my bearings here... Who is this again?
Phil, I gotta get back to work, was there anything else you told me to do after I came out of it?
If you're asking if I gave you a post-
Post-hypnotic suggestion, I know what it's called, Phil. Did you leave any others behind when you were kickin' your big, clumsy-ass feet around inside my brain?
No.
Tell me the truth, Phil!
No, I swear! I went out of my way not to, I even added a thing at the end to make sure!
What thing?
I, I didn't want you to retain any of the experience, you know, I wanted you to have control back, so I made up this thing. (CONTINUED)
What thing?

text: Oh, my God! She bounds up the steps, calling out for Jake.
She can't be that far! He runs to the corner, desperate, and looks up and down t street in both directions. There are a lot of people out, could be anywhere.
He turns, looks up and down the side street. Nothing in t first direction, but when he looks the other way, he hear faint BUZZING sound in the distance. He doesn't hesitate, just takes off toward it.

Tom is running as hard as he can. He stops, abruptly. The buzzing sound is gone. He looks to his right. Behind a wa there is a large parking lot filled with buses. He turns around. A dull white glow comes from the windows the place on the corner. He looks up, at the sign. It's a Greyhound bus station. Wait right here, keep your eyes open! He opens the door and goes inside.

Tom steps into the station, still breathing hard. The BUZ sound returns. But from where? Is it in his mind this tim or really here, in the bus station? The place is empty except for one person, sitting on a wo bench with their back to him, near the departure doors. T walks slowly across the place to the figure. It's Dorothy As he draws closer, he sees Jake's face, over Dorothy's shoulder. Jake's eyes are open, and he's staring up at th ceiling. Tom follows his son's gaze. Jake is staring up at the lig the old-style fluorescent tubes that give the place its cancerous look. The tubes BUZZ loudly. It's the sound Tom been hearing. Jake sees his father and smiles. Tom puts a finger to his lips -- "Shhhh." Jake yawns, closes his eyes, and drops h head onto Dorothy's shoulder. He goes back to sleep. Tom walks slowly around the end of the bench. Dorothy is SINGING softly, an old nursery rhyme. She looks up suddenly and sees Tom. She starts to jerk to feet. Tom puts a hand out -- take it easy. Dorothy sits back, caught. Tom steps closer to her, carefully. He hold both his hands out, palms up. (CONTINUED)

Give him to me. She shakes her head no. Outside, a SIREN WHINES and a pol car flashes past the window, its red lights spinning. The both hear it and glance over, then look back at each othe Tom raises an eyebrow. She knows what he means. TOM (cont'd) Give him to me, Dorothy. Trembling, Dorothy reaches out, Jake in her arms. (half asleep) Oh, hi, Mommy. She's relieved, but livid.
(to Dorothy) What the hell is the matter with you?! Dorothy jumps to her feet and races through the door that leads to the back, where the buses leave from.
(to Maggie) Take him home! I'll be there as soon as I can! He runs after Dorothy.

Dorothy races out of the bus station and into the forest parked buses. Tom comes out a few seconds later, giving chase. Sit up. Sit up, I want to talk to you. She manages to drag herself into a sitting position. She shoves back, against the wheel of a bus. Go away.

He told me! He told me so! The DRIVER of the bus that nearly hit her is out of his b now. He SHOUTS at them from the other side of the lot.
Jake said that? (she nods) What else did he say?

Nothing. I was sitting there, I was watching him sleep, I was just watching him, like I'm supposed to, and... and he sat up in bed, he looked right at me, and he said "I'm not safe in this house." Two times, he said it, and then he went back to sleep.
Where were you taking him? (CONTINUED)
California. To my father's house. My real father, not -- (like poison on her tongue) -- Duane. Jake would be safe at my father's house, we'd both be safe there.

You too? (she nods) Why aren't you safe here? She doesn't answer. The Driver is coming over to them, st SHOUTING. TOM (cont' d) Dorothy? Dorothy, why aren't you safe here? The Driver is still closer. INT TOM i MAGGIE'S HOUSE NIGHT The red light glows on the baby monitor, and Jake's breat can be heard from in his bedroom. Tom and Maggie sit on t couch in their living room, the nonitor beside them, just light on. He has his arms arounc' her, holding her tight. hand is bandaged. They're shaker..

If she was, she's very quick getting in and out of a room.
Where was she? When you saw her, where was she exactly?
On the cushion right next to you. Maggie looks down at the empty half of the couch, freaked She pulls in closer to him.

If your brain is tearing in half?

I want you to go see my cousin Elizabeth. Make sure there's nothing wrong. Just tell her about the headaches, that's all she needs to know, you don't have to bring up the other stuff. Suddenly, he smiles. (CONTINUED)
Hey, know what? (she looks at him) It is a girl. She furrows her brow, "how do you know?", then follows hi gaze down to her belly, where his hand is resting.

Tom, dressed in a patient's gown, walks down a hospital corridor with DR. ELIZABETH NOONAN, fortyish. Elizabeth m notes on a clipboard, walking and talking fast, all busin Elizabeth does not have the human touch.
Do you have any metal plates in your skull?
Any shrapnel lodged anywhere in your body?
No.
No cardiac pacemaker, I assume -- iron filings near your eyes?
Huh?
You don't work with sheet metal, do you?
No.
Left here. (CONTINUED)
They turn down another corridor. ELIZABETH (cont' d) Do you have an inner ear transplant?
No.
Aneurism clips in your brain?
No thanks.
Do you suffer from claustrophobia?
Only in, like, really small spaces. (she looks at him, straight
You have a great sense of humor.
Right, then jog left. They do.
Do we really gotta do this?

You've had no head trauma, no serious viral infections you can recall, you haven't been out of the country, you're not a drug user, you have no history of migraines... I suppose I could open up your skull in the operating room and then decide what to do, but I'd rather take a few pictures first, wouldn't you? She pushes through a set of double doors.

The MRI machine is a long tunnel with a body slab stickin obscenely, like a tongue. TWO NURSES stand on either side it. One wall of the room is glass, behind the glass are t TECHNICIANS -- and Maggie, who waves supportively. Tom swallows. (CONTINUED)
How's it work? Elizabeth goes to a computer terminal and types in some commands.

It creates an electromagnetic field thirty thousand times stronger than the earth's. That stimulates your brain's protons to align themselves. Then we shoot radio waves into you, which knocks the protons out of alignment. They then realign themselves, sending out radio signals we record on the scanner. The computer reads the signals and makes a series of detailed cross-sections of the layers of tissue. Tom looks at the machine, then back at her.
Can I have another Valium?
Tom lies down on the "tongue." The Nurses wrap sheets aro his arms and tuck them in under his body, immobilizing th He looks at one of them questioningly.
So your arms don't touch the sides of the machine.
That would be bad? She smiles and nods. The other Nurse puts a white cloth o his hair.
Your party hat. He tries to smile, but he is unnerved. Elizabeth leans in staring down at Tom.
It's so nice you and Maggie finally came to see me at work.
a Technician hits a series of switches.
the tongue starts to move, sliding into the tunnel. Tom l still, staring upward as he is pulled inside, like a corp a drawer sliding back into the wall of the morgue.
it's only about two feet across, and less from top to bot Tom blinks, staring up at the ceiling as the tongue comes stop. It's incredibly claustrophobic.
Kinda hot in the coffin. ELIZABETH'S VOICE comes blaring out of speakers mounted o either side of the tunnel.

the giant "hammers" that are contained in the cylinders t surround the tunnel start to move, slowly at first.

the hammers pick up speed, and these things move. It gets noisy fast.

they can hear the thundering hammers, the blaring music, above it all, Tom's crazy kind of laughter. Elizabeth looks at Maggie.
Three electronic screens, two red and one whitish-blue, display various cross-sections of Tom's brain. Graphs and columns of numbers are listed alongside.
No tumors, no growths, no scars or lesions, no intrusions or damaged tissue of any kind. Except for one tiny abnormality, your brain anatomy is textbook. Physically, anyway. (CONTINUED)
What abnormality?

Well, it's so insignificant it's hardly worth mentioning. She leans forward to one of the screens and points to a s on a cross-section. ELIZABETH (cont' d) It's the parietal lobe. Here. There's a slight distension, just the tiniest bulge here in the arc of the crescent. That's uncommon.
How uncommon?
One in a half million, maybe, it doesn't really have a name. But it isn't consequential. Wouldn't have any effect on cognitive processes.

Great. There's nothing wrong with me, I gotta get back to work. (stands and shakes hands) Thank you for everything, Elizabeth, I owe you a giant one, hey, you think I can get some of that Valium to go? Elizabeth scowls at him. TOM (cont' d) Worth a try. Take care, say hi to Michael. (to Maggie) I'll pick up Jake, I told him I'd take him to the Pier tonight. He heads for the door, eager to get the hell out of there Maggie lingers, looking at Elizabeth, hopeful.

Maggie. I said nothing physical.

Maggie is in the bedroom, cleaning up. She picks up Tom's pair of jeans from the floor and folds them over one arm. Something THUNKS to the floor. She picks it up. It's the butterfly knife, the one he took from Duane. She stares at it, fascinated and frightened. She lets it drop open. There is dried blood on the blade. Gingerly, she closes it again. She opens a drawer and put in, then thinks better of that. She takes it out again, l for a place to put it. She drops it in her purse and zips it shut. She'll deal w it later.

Navy Pier is an amusement park/shopping mall built on a p jutting out into Lake Michigan. It's a nice night, the pi is crowded, just enough urban edge to be interesting. A figure bobs along above the crowd -- Jake, sitting on Tom shoulders. They stop and join a CROWD watching a JUGGLER, good one, keeps five burning pins in the air. Jake suddenly looks up, confused by something. He stares the juggler, through the flames. Behind the juggler, a UNIFORMED COP is staring at the little boy -- it's the sa Cop who was parked outside their house earlier. Jake star back, the flaming pins flying up between them. Tom moves on, his boy still on his shoulders. The Cop tur and watches them go. Jake turns, looking back over his shoulder at the Cop. The Cop raises a hand and waves. Jak just stares.
there is an elaborate model train set on display in the window.
Daddy, look!
Woah, check it out. He stops, helps Jake down off his shoulders. Jake presses right up against the glass, staring at the train as it ci the track. Tom squats, admiring it with him. (CONTINUED)
the Cop is still watching them. He walks closer, stops on about ten feet away, staring. Tom glances up, sees him, thinks nothing of it. The 'op steps closer.
Tom sees the reflection of the Cop. Closer now, staring. turns and smiles, tight-lipped. He recognizes him from th other day. The Cop smiles back, doesn't go away.
(to Jake) Hey, look at that one! He carries Jake to the next window over, a different disp The Cop wanders closer. Tom finally turns to him, tense. TOM (cont' d) How ya doin'?
Fine, fine. He's staring at Jake.
Is there a law against lookin' in the window now?
Huh? Oh, no, `course not. I'm off duty. I live right up there.
That's great. See ya later. He sweeps Jake up onto one hip and starts to walk away.
It's even stronger in him than it is in you. Tom stops. Turns back.
What? The Cop smiles and makes a face -- "you heard me." (CONTINUED)
TOM (cont' d) I don't know what you're talking about.

Jon't be afraid of it. Tom just star .s at the Cop, trembling slightly. The Cop forward. Fascinated, Tom does not back away. The Cop lowe his voice. COP (cont' d) You're not alone. Tom is too rattled to speak. COP (cont' d) You don't know about Cacophony yet? Tom shakes his head no. The Cop pulls out a note pad, scribbles something on a page, tears it out and holds it to Tom. COP (cont' d) Come next time. His hand shaking, Tom accepts the paper. The Cop reaches and tousles Jake's hair. COP (coast' d) Bye, Jake. The Cop turns and walks away.
Bye, Neil! The Cop looks back over his shoulder and smiles. Tom look his son as if he's never seen him before.

Jake, fresh from a bath and in his pajamas, sits on the f of his room, playing with model cars, intent. He's HUMMIN soft tune to himself, the same one he hummed during his b in the opening. Tom and Maggie sit near him, staring at him. They're frea out. What have they got on their hands here? Their tone i soft, gently probing. (CONTINUED)

Jake, do you remember the other day when we were talking in the kitchen? Jake doesn't look up, just keeps playing and HUMMING. MAGGIE (cont' d) I was loo3.ing for a baby-sitter, remember? (Jake plays) And you said "Samantha" told you about Dorothy. Do you remember that? He keeps playing, HUMMING.
Jake? Mommy's asking you a question. Nothing.
Is Samantha someone who talks to you sometimes, Jake? No answer. She tries a different route. MAGGIE (cont'd) Can you remember any of the things that Saman- Jake looks up sharply.

Don't ask the boy any more questions. They freeze, staring at him. His tone was odd. And did he just refer to himself in the third person? JAKE (cant' d) Talk to me. He goes back to playing, and to that little tune. It's becoming rather haunting. Maggie and Tom look at each other. Good God.
Nighttime. Tom and Maggie are asleep in bed. Suddenly, To eyes pop open. (CONTINUED)

She's downstairs. He sits up. His head is killing him again. There's a glas of water on the night table. le grabs it and drinks greed He turns and looks to the open -loorway. He swallows. He stands up. He looks down at Maggie, who's still sound asleep. He walks to the door. Maggie stirs, feeling him gone.

Tom walks down the narrow hallway, toward the staircase a far end. He's scared. He starts down the stairs. Halfway down, he dares a look through the wooden posts that support the handrail. Samantha is standing in the middle of the room. She looks up at him. For a long moment, they just stare a each other. Steam rises lightly from her as she breathes. Tom is shaking, barely finds his voice.

Samantha? She speaks, but when her voice comes out it's horrible an distorted -- muffled in a strange way. He takes a few trembling steps down the stairs, closer to She walks forward a step or two. She speaks again, louder but the voice is still unintelligible and bizarre. Tom reaches the bottom of the stairs. She reaches out a h He stares, terrified. The hand draws closer. Almost beyond his own control, Tom raises his own hand. She comes closer. Tom is frozen at the bottom of the stairs. Their hands dr closer still. Their fingertips touch. (CONTINUED)

Tom GASPS, as if something very heavy were put down on hi chest. His mouth drops open, his chest twitches. He can't breathe. They stand there, frozen in that position. Tom tries, but can't draw air. MAGGIE'S VOICE calls out from the top ci the stairs.

Tom? He can't answer. He's panicked, but unable to move. With every twitch of his chest clouds of steam burst from his mouth, all the air going out, none coming in. From the top of the stairs, Maggie can see him, standing there, hand outstretched into the darkness, touching noth But from Tom's point of view, he's touching fingertips wi Samantha. He's frozen, breathless, and now his cheeks sta to turn pale, unnaturally white. Another few seconds of t and he'll pass out. MAGGIE (con t' d) Tom!? She races down the stairs. MAGGIE (cont' d)

Tom can't look at her, can't move. A tear rolls down his cheek as his lips begin to turn blue. MAGGIE (cont' d) TOM, BR. ATfHE! She grabs hold of him. As soon as Maggie makes contact, T collapses. He sees Samantha break away from him with a SH of irritation. She moves, not quite walking, but a herky- jerky kind of lateral movement toward the dining room, fa like someone on a dozen espressos, an angry thing that ha slow itself down to a crawl just to talk to us. In the dining room, she flops over onto the floor, like a reflection appearing suddenly on the surface of a pond. I the floor, she disappears. Maggie grabs Tom's face and turns it toward her. He takes big lungful of air. (CONTINUED)
MAGGIE (cont' d) Was she here?! Tom nods, sucking air greedily. MAGGIE (cont'd) Why?!
I think we better find out.

It's a street party, and it's jammed. Police barricades a at both ends of the block. Half barrels of beer sit in bi plastic garbage cans, ice dumped over them. Everyone seem have agreed on which radio station to listen to, and most the couple dozen cars parked in the driveways have their radios tuned to it, loud, the windows hanging open. Outside Bernie's Tap, the bar on the corner, a DOZEN DRUN GUYS are running pass patterns out the front door, cuttin left at the mailbox, and catching a football thrown from inside the bar, out an open window. Well, they don't actu catch the ball...
the Homeless Guy we've seen on the street a few times is drinking right out of one of the beer taps while nobody i watching. Lenny, the local crank we met before, is outrag

head_text.subj: HEY, GET THE HELL AWAY FROM THERE

text: He chases him off, trying to kick him in the ass but spil his own beer in the process. LENNY (cont' d) (to no one in particular) You see what I'm talkin' about?! You see what I mean?!
Jake plays with a couple other NEIGHBORHOOD KIDS.
Frank is giving a lurid lesson on the proper way to pump keg to two ATTRACTIVE YOUNG WOMEN. Tom joins him. (CONTINUED)
- - .Err- r - - - - ab a. ter. s
You know you're under surveillance here. He gestures to Sheila, Frank's wife, who's about ten feet away, keeping an angry eye on him.
What can I do? Nature commands me to spread my seed. I hear and obey.
Sure, great, just don't be surprised if some day Sheila digs out your 38 and buries a slug or two in your ass.
Please. The woman can't even step on a spider.
Spider doesn't fuck around on her.
Sheila is talking to Maggie, disgusted with Frank.
They change, Maggie. Ten or so years of marriage, a kid or two -- they become a different human being.
Sheila, if you're so miserable, why don't you leave? Adam's almost out of school, he can handle it.
Oh, Frank would love that. No. I want him out. I like that house.
How long have you guys been there?
Almost fifteen years.
So... you know most of the people around here pretty well, right?
somebody actually manages to catch one of the passes comi from out of the bar and is immediately tackled by three drunks. On the pavement. Ouch.
Tom is now talking to Harry Damon.

But, you know, what am I gonna do, I'm a single father with a son to support, I can' t just say fuck everything. So I scraped together enough money to make a few downpayments, and here I am. A landlord, for Christ's sake.
So you've been in this neighborhood a long time, right?
is questioning Sheila.
Did you ever hear of a girl named Samantha Muller?
(THINKS)
From over by Baldwin?
I think so.
Yeah, kinda, name rings a bell.
in response to the same question from Tom, calls over to son Kurt, the good-looking football player, who is leanin against the front of his yellow Trans-Am, talking to a co other guys.
Hey, Kurt, you remember that Muller girl? (to Tom) Like he ever tells me anything. (CONTINUED)
The music coming from the car is too loud, Kurt can't hea HARRY (cont' d) (SHOUTING)
He gestures. Kurt drags himself off the hood and saunters over. HARRY (cont' d) Do you remember that Muller girl?
What, Dorothy? He makes a "big breasts" gesture.
No, the other one. Samantha. Lenny, the crank, joins the conversation.
You mean the retard? She ran away.
She did?
is on the same subject.
She was always hanging around the guys, you know, she wanted to be with the "in" clique and everything. There wasn't much chance of that.
asks Tom a question.
Why you wanna know about her?

Oh, Dorothy baby-sits for us sometimes and she started talking about her sister, wonderin' how she was doing and stuff. I promised her I'd ask around, see if anybody'd heard anything from her. (CONTINUED)
- - - Ambb. - - - - - Nft - & a r-
She took off back in March, I think, with some black guy.
)id she ever live in that house we're .n? Frank comes up, one arm around his son Adam.
Who?
No. You're the first tenants since I bought it.
(to Harry) Harry, I saw those Dominicans back in the park again. By the basketball courts?
What do you want me to do about it, Lenny?
We could go talk to `em. Scare `em off, if there were enough of us.
Yeah, Lenny, they're gonna be terrified of you.
keeps talking to Maggie.

She was a pretty girl, but real shy. Pretty simple. She had these crazy ideas she could be an actress, you know. She thought she was gonna be a big movie star. I mean, there was no way, but you couldn't tell her that. I thought it was kind of sad.
have joined Tom and the others. (CONTINUED)
(to Tom) Two one one.
Okay.
Got it.
Two hundred eleven.
I give up, Frank.

(puts his son in a hammerlock) Two hundred and eleven yards rushing the other night. That makes eight ninety-four with two games to play, kid needs a hundred and six, that's only fifty-three a game. He could walk through the rest of the season and hit a thousand.

(pulling free) Dad... Behind them, the guys playing football out of Bernie's Ta have now organized a full-fledged game of tackle in the street, over the objections of their wives and girlfriend who shout at them to stop.
I embarrass him. Are there worse things that can happen to a human being?
Hey, Adam, way to go, man.
(SHYLY)
Thanks. (CONTINUED)
(to Harry) Well, if you hear anything about her, lemme know, okay?
About who?
Tom's askin' about that Muller girl from over by Baldwin, you know, the one that ran away?
The retard.
Jesus, Lenny, don't use that word.
What, retard?
(SARCASTIC)
No, "the."
She was almost your age, Adam. You know anything about her? Adam doesn't answer right away. They all look at him.

Huh uh. Suddenly, the guys playing football run a play right thro the middle of them -- sweaty, middle-aged bodies fly in e direction. Everybody SHOUTS and lunges backward, protecti their beers. The conversation is broken up. But the football players are upset, and a fight breaks ou The crowd gets out of the way, half to watch the fight wi glee, the other half to shake their heads and watch the f
while the fight goes on in the background, Adam wanders a from the group and sits down on the hood of Kurt Damon's He's rattled. Kurt notices him and comes over. He sits ne to him. (CONTINUED)
You okay?
Yeah. (Kurt is looking atIhim: I'm fine.
You don't look fine.
Really, Mom? How do I look?
(hands up in surrender) All right, all right. Just, if there's, you know, if there's somethin' you wanna bullshit about or anything, just let me know. Might help.
You could climb off my back, that'd help. Adam walks away.
Sorry.

head_text.subj: AT THE END OF THE BLOCK,

text: two police cars arrive, their lights flashing. COPS jump and wade through the crowd to bust up the fight. So much the party. Sheila shakes her head.
It can't ever just be nice. Someone's always got to ruin it.

Nighttime. The city lights are on. The sound of SOBBING rises faintly over them. We're on the roof of a house, an figure with its back to us is doing the crying. The figur drinks from a bottle. A long, hard pull. (CONTINUED)
Coming around thefrontwe see the figure is Adam McCarthy, Frank and Sheila'sson,sitting on the roof of his house, staring out at thecityand getting quietly shit-faced.
Tom pries his eyes open, exhausted. Sunlight streams thro the window, right into his face. He squints, looks at the clock. It's 10:26.
Oh, man... He sits up, painfully. A beam of sunlight cuts him right across the eyes.

Tom pulls his jeans on. He sits on a chair, puts on a sho But the other one's gone. He feels under the chair. Not there. He opens the closet door. Not there. He looks under the bed. There it is. He grabs it.
A note is taped to the bathroom mirror -- "WENT TO THE PA
Tom takes it down and reads it.

Tom comes downstairs and heads for the kitchen. There's someone standing in his living room, in the doorway from dining room. It's Frank, his neighbor from next door, wea a red shirt. Frank is staring at the floor.
Frank? What are you doing here? Frank looks up at him. His face is sad.
They're going to kill you, Tommy. You and Maggie both. (CONTINUED)
Frank turns and walks to the front door. He opens it, wal outside, and sits on the top step of the porch, looking o the street. Tom follows him.
It's a beautiful day, but the street is still kind of a m from the party yesterday. Tom comes out and looks down at Frank, who's just sitting there, staring out at the litte
Why did you say that, Frank?

(in his own world) This is a decent neighborhood. On the street, TWO KIDS ride their bikes straight at each other, full tilt, SCREAMING. At the last second, one of t kids swerves, the other taunts him with cries of "Chicken A bird swoops over Tom's head, too low, and Tom flinches. walks across the driveway, toward Frank's house. The MAIL waves to him, headed down the block. Tom waves back. Tom walks up the steps to Frank's front door and knocks. VOICE calls from inside. ADAM (o.s.) Come in!
Tom opens the door and comes in. Adam, Frank's son, is standing in the middle of the living room floor, a big sm on his face and one arm behind his back.
Hi!
Hi.
Want to see what I've got?
Sure. Adam pulls his arm around from behind his back. He's hold a 38 with a carved white handle. (CONTINUED)
TOM (cont' d) Is that your dad's?

Not today. Come here: Tom walks toward him. ADAM (cont' d) Closer. Tom walks closer. He's right in front of Adam. ADAM (cont' d) I bet you never saw this before. He points the gun barrel at Tom -- -- then swings it around and points it at his own heart.
Oh, don't do that. Adam pulls the trigger. Tom SCREAMS as Adam collapses to the floor, blood pouring his chest. His body convulses --
-- and Tom's eyes pop open, in bed. That was weird. Tom blinks, exhausted. Sunlight streams through the windo right into his face. He squints, looks at the clock. It's 10:26.
Oh, man... He sits up, painfully. A beam of sunlight cuts him right across the eyes.

Tom pulls on a pair of jeans. He sits down, puts on a sho But the other one's gone. He feels under the chair. Not there. He opens the closet door. Not there. Tom blinks, unsettle This is kinda familiar. He turns and looks at the bed. (CONTINUED)
Please don't be under there. He bends down, lifts the blanket, and looks under the bed There's his shoe. TOM (cont' d) Shit. He grabs it.
A note is taped to the bathroom mirror -- "WENT TO THE PA
Tom winces as he takes it down and reads it. Again.
Shod, Tom comes down the stairs and into the living room. Frank's not there, thank God. Tom goes to the front door and opens it.
Uh... Frank? But Frank's not on the porch either. Tom steps outside.

It's a beautiful day, but the street is still kind of a m from the party yesterday. A SHOUT draws Tom's attention. Those same two kids ride their bikes at each other, full Tom walks down the steps of the porch, staring at them as SCREAM. At the last second, one of the kids turns away. T other taunts him with cries of "Chicken!" Tom stands frozen on the sidewalk. A bird swoops low over head; he really flinches this time. The Mailman waves to headed down the block. Too stunned, Tom doesn't wave back He turns, panicked, and looks at Frank's house. He starts walk toward it, slowly at first, then picking up speed, jogging across the driveway. He's halfway there -- -- when a GUNSHOT rings out from inside.
Oh, God... (CONTINUED)
He races the rest of the way, bounds up the steps to the house, rips open the screen door. But the front door is locked. He POUNDS on it. TOM (coast' d)
He POUNDS harder, but there's no answer. He goes to the window beside the door and peers through it.
he sees Adam lying on the floor in the middle of the livi room.
Oh, God, no! Tom picks up a porch chair and heaves it through the wind

Glass SHATTERS and sprays all over the floor. Tom knocks rest out of the frame with his elbow and climbs into the house. He races over to Adam's body. There is a pool of blood ar his chest and his body is convulsing. In his right hand, clutches a 38 with a carved white handle.
Oh, God, no, Jesus, no, please... He grabs a blanket off a chair nearby, presses it to Adam chest, trying to stop the bleeding. TOM (cont' d) This is really happening.., it's really happening...
Tom sits on his front steps, shell shocked, red light fla off his face. An ambulance and two police cars are parked front of the house next door, radios SQUAWKING with offic activity. (CONTINUED)

Tom just stares. A car comes barreling around the corner SQUEALS to a halt in front of the house. Frank and Sheila leap out of the car and race toward the house. Tom watches as they're intercepted-by a COP who tries to restrain them for a second. But they're hysterical, they' obviously been told something serious has happened and th desperate to get inside. They blow past the Cop and hurry up the stairs, just as T PARAMEDICS wheel a stretcher out of the house, headed for ambulance. The sheet isn't over Adam's head, at least, bu that's about the only good sign, they're working on him frantically. Tom buries his head in his lap as he hears the cries of A parents -- Frank's anguished, disbelieving BELLOW, Sheila horrified SCREAM.

CLOSE ON a torn off piece of notebook paper with an addre and a time scribbled on it. The word "Cacophony" is legib Maggie picks it up, stares at it for a moment, then hands to Tom, who is by the front door, zipping his jacket. He takes it and shoves it in his pocket. He's nervous. They both are. She smooths his jacket. He turns to go, but she tightens her grip on his jacket. Doesn't want to let him
We need some answers, right? Maybe they're the only ones who have any. She nods. Thinking of something, she picks up her car key from the table by the door and pulls something off the ri

I'm sure they're very nice people, but in case they aren't -- She hands a thin black cannister to him. MAGGIE (coat' d) Mace the shit out of `em. He smiles and shoves it in his pocket. She kisses him.
Tom walks down a street in a dodgy neighborhood at night, checking addresses. He stops and looks up, at an old, formerly grand apartment building that's fallen on hard t
The corridor is even creepier. And massive. Tom reaches a door all the way at the end and knocks. A moment later, t door opens. A very heavy-set woman in a floral print dres (VIVIAN) smiles at him.
I hope you like fondue!

Vivian sets a plate down on a TV tray in front of Tom. Th is a pile of chunks of various hard-to-identify meats, a silver fondue spear, and a chocolate cupcake with an Amer flag stuck in it. Tom sits on an overstuffed couch that's leaking stuffing.
Dip away!

Thank you. Listen, is, uh -- Vivian gives another plate to a man sitting next to Tom, HERMAN, in his seventies, in a wheelchair, an oxygen tube running into his nostrils. TOM (coat' d) Is there a guy named Neil here? He's a cop?

Well, of course he is! She turns and heads back into the kitchen, passing BEVERL her identical twin, who's wearing the same print dress, t one with a red background instead of blue. Beverly serves people on the far couch, one a THIRTEEN YEAR OLD GIRL, th other a HOMEY in his early twenties. Tom picks up a ham chunk and looks at the steaming fondue full of cheese. Beverly dips and eats, winks at him, and flits off across the room. Herman turns to Tom and asks something in a raspy voice. (CONTINUED)
Excuse me? Irritated, Herman gestures for him to lean closer. Tom do
What does it want you to do?
I don't... I'm sorry, I don't under- Herman wraps his bony fingers around Tom's wrist.

Then you're not listening! NEIL (o.s.) It's his first time, Herman. Give him a break. Tom turns. Neil, the cop he saw the other night, has come from the kitchen. Tonight he's in street clothes. NEIL (cont' d) (points at Tom) Lemme guess. "Distended parietal lobe," right?
(AMAZED)
Who are you guys?

Don't have a name. Cacophony Society, somebody said once, that stuck for a while. You know, like too many voices in our heads? I think it's too melodramatic. How about "fellow sufferers?" Vivian comes in from the kitchen with two big gallon jugs orange juice. There are AAAAHS1 of appreciation.
Does everybody here -- see things, like me?
(NODS)
Buncha freaks, huh?
Speak for yourself. (CONTINUED)

No, Herman, you're a freak. "Mutants" is a better word for the rest of us. He pulls 'ip a chair and sits down opposite Tom. On the o side of tie room, Vivian and Beverly tell an animated two story to he teenage girl and the homey, finishing each others' se. .tences . NEIL (cont' d) Like any other part of our body, our brains have evolved a lot in a hundred thousand years. Our first thoughts were formless. Struggling consciousness. Sensation. An instinctive tie to our environment. But then our brains began to focus. We sacrificed the intuitions we first had so our thoughts could be directed, so we could master specific functions. That's where we are at the moment. We're brilliant with technique, but we've given up instinct. So the next evolutionary step, the step yet to come, or perhaps it's already in the making, is actually backward. To maintain our higher functions, but reawaken the part of our brain that was pure intuition. That was receptive to anything, because it didn't know enough not to believe. You're a freak of nature, pal, an evolutionary step. You're double- jointed. (taps his head) Up here.
Are we the only ones?

Hardly. I've heard of groups like ours in San Francisco, New York, Minneapolis -- those are just the cities I've been to. Tom, you're what they used to call a medium. You're like a man in a dark tunnel with a flashlight, but the light only goes on once in a while. When it flickers on, you get a glimpse of something, but not enough of a glimpse to know what it is. Just enough to know it's there. (CONTINUED)
What about my son?
(sn files) The ncxt generation. Much better flashlight.
Wright, if there's all these people who got this power, why doesn't everybody know about it? Why isn't it common knowledge?

It is. A lotta people know. Unfortunately, the easiest people to convince, the believer types, they also tend to be the dumbest. And people who demand proof -- well, this isn't something we can control, it comes when it comes, so if you can't make it happen, how can you prove it? It's like that singing frog in the cartoon, but when the guy puts it on stage it just croaks and he looks like a jerk. Herman laughs, horribly. He likes that cartoon. NEIL (cont' d) Some of us try anyway. I say who needs that kind of aggravation?
This all started when I was hypnotized. Is that how it always is?
First time I've heard that one. it comes all different ways. Sometimes it goes the same way it came.
So it does go away.
For some people. Don't look for rules. We're off the map here.
What does it want you to do? (CONTINUED)
What does what want me to do?
You saw a ghos-, didn't you?
Yeah. Twice. t. girl that disappeared from my neighborhood. Now the kid next door just tried to kill himself. I think he knew something, but now I'll never know what it was. And I gotta know.
Look, what'd the bitch want?
Why do you assume she wants something?
They always do. Something they need finished, something they can't do any more.
Why me?

Because she's confused. Doesn't know why other people won't answer her. She only knows that you will. If she hasn't asked for something yet, she will. And once they ask, it's very difficult to stop yourself from doing it.
What do you mean? She can, it can make me do something I don't want to do?
Oh, no. You'll want to. Badly. You won't think about anything else. You won't sleep. You won't eat. You'll lie. And God help anyone who tries to stop you.
What if I stop me? What if I just don't do it? (CONTINUED)
Then you got a weird bitch friend for the rest of your life.
Just listen to her, Tom Let her tell you what she wants.
A HAND pounds on an apartment door. Philip opens up. He w asleep.
What, what, what?
I want you to hypnotize me again.
Tom paces the floor in Philip's apartment.

Just slow down, you gotta be a little patient with me here, `cause, um... well, Tom, Tom, I've got a confession to make. See I, I, I just smoked this great big fatty a few minutes before you walked in, so this shit you're tellin' me here is fuckin' with my mind just a little bit extra, okay? Tom grabs a chair from Philip's desk and sits.
Do it.
they sit face to face.
Okay. Close your eyes. Tom closes his eyes.

PHILIP (o.s.) Just like last time -- I want you to concentrate. Listen to the room around you. Tom listens. The factory CHURNS softly outsioi the window A few CARS in the street below. His BREATHING. PHILIP (cont' d) Now focus. Concentrate. Look at the backs of your eyelids. Do you see anything there?
(opens his eyes) Would you just get to it, please?
All right, all right. Tom closes his eyes again. PHILIP (cont' d) I want you to pretend you're in a movie theatre.

We're sitting alone in an empty movie theatre. The seats walls are covered in black velvet. PHILIP (o.s.) It's very dark. Everything is covered in black velvet. The seats, the walls, the floor. In the whole pitch- black theatre, there's only one thing you can see. The white screen. You drift toward it, in your chair. Up ahead of us, the screen is a dazzling white. We move slowly toward it, floating over the seats. PHILIP (o.s.) There are letters up on the screen. Tall, thick, black letters, but they're out of focus. You drift closer to them. (CONTINUED)
We do drift closer to the blurry letters, but our attenti diverted by something. Three rows from the screen, there figure in one of the seats, its back to us.
Tom's eyes are sill closed. His face furrows in conctrn.
There's someone in here.
No, it's empty.
There's someone else here.
No, man, I said you're alone in the theatre.

But there is someone in the theatre with us, and we conti to drift forward toward them. PHILIP (o . s . ) You're comfortable in your black velvet seat, very comfortable... Actually, we're quite nervous, drifting closer and closer that figure sitting in the third row, its back to us. PHILIP (o . s . ) Your feet and ankles are relaxed. Your legs are relaxed.
Tom's eyes are still closed. His chest is twitching.
hard to breathe
The figure in the seat is only a row or two ahead of us n It's a woman. We keep drifting closer. PHILIP (o . s . ) Your hands are limp and heavy. Your arms are relaxed. Your face. (CONTINUED)

Our hand reaches out, touches the shoulder of the woman. turns. It's Samantha. Her face is shrouded in plastic. Her mouth presses against the plastic, it forms a horrible round 0, contorted in a silent scream.
Tom's eyes flicker madly under the lids. Philip's worried
I want you to look at the screen.
(GASPING)
I can't breathe!
Look at the screen, Tom.

Now Tom's not just an observer in the movie theatre, he's the movie theatre, sitting right next to Samantha. She's pawing at him, it's all he can do to fight her hands off. their struggle, his fingers close around the plastic that shrouds her face. He sweeps it off her head. PHILIP (o.s.) The screen, Tom, look at the screen! You can read the letters now! Maggie drives, as fast as she can. Up ahead, red lights f and gates fall in front of a set of railroad tracks. Trai coming. Cars are stopped, waiting for it. Maggie pulls to a stop at the back of the line -- -- then thinks better of it. She drops the car in gear, h it around the others, and bolts for the tracks. The train nearly upon her, BLARES its horn. Maggie flies across the tracks and SLAMS through the gate the other side, a split-second before the train HURTLES through the intersection behind her. She cuts it hard to the right to miss the waiting cars on other side, and pulls it back on the road. She drives on, shaking like a leaf.
Frank is still sobbing, his back to Tom. Tom takes a step toward him, to comfort him.
I mean...

I mean, what were we supposed to do? Tom stops. FRANK (cont' d) The kids come to us, she's already dead, the damage is done, there's nothin' gonna bring her back. But those boys, they've got everything ahead of them. Frank lets his jacket drop to the floor, revealing his ri hand. He's holding the 38 with the carved white handle. He turns and looks at Tom. (CONTINUED)
FRANK (coast' d) What were we supposed to do? Send our boys to jail for the rest of their lives? Our own flesh and blood? Over her?

I think you haven't decided yet. He's right, and Frank knows it.

What are you gonna do, Frank? Frank raises the gun, in a fury.

A NEWBORN BABY stares up at us from inside a rolling bass The bassinet is wheeled swiftly down a hospital corridor NURSE. It's a long trip, wherever it's going, but the bab waits patiently, staring up at the ceiling, eyes open. Above the baby, the lights streak by, white blurs. The Nurse leans down and looks at the baby. To the baby, she's just a fuzzy blob.
Almost there! (CONTINUED)

The baby turns and looks sideways. The doors of the hospi rooms whiz by, brown smears. NURSE (cont' d) Just around this corner! She rolls the bassinet around a corner and toward one or particular. The baby sees a bunch of shapes inside the room.

Let me see, let me see! Maggie turns the baby so she's facing Jake. The infant lo at her older brother. At first, his face is as blurry as everybody else's. But slowly, Jake's face becomes crystal clear, even though everything around him stays out of foc JAKE (cont' d) Can I hold her?
If you're very, very careful. Climb up here. (CONTINUED)

Well, they... certainly get along, don't they? Suddenly, Jake breaks into a wide grin and looks up at hi parents, thrilled. Then he looks back at his sister. He leans down and whispers softly in her ear.
